The tragedy of Palestinian construction workers, banned from Israel
subhead: Since October 7, 2023, the Netanyahu government has revoked the work permits of 120,000 Palestinians from the West Bank. With no other resources, hundreds of them risk their lives every day to try to cross the separation wall illegally.

title: Trump decides not to deploy National Guard in San Francisco
subhead: The US president had planned to make the California metropolis a symbol of a city abandoned to crime and headed for ruin under Democratic leadership, and had considered sending in the military to restore order.

title: A former mining city in northern China has become a budget tourist destination
subhead: Driven by the reconstruction of its downtown area and the redevelopment of disused mining sites, China's northern city of Datong, located 350 kilometers west of Beijing, has been experiencing a boost in tourism.

title: Michel Devoret, 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics laureate, has fun in the quantum tunnel
subhead: Honored by the Swedish Academy alongside his colleagues John Clarke and John Martinis for research conducted 40 years ago, the French scientist now wants to engage with young people to popularize his field.

Three years after taking power in Italy, Meloni is dropping the mask
subhead: Appointed in October 2022, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has reassured Brussels and financial markets, notably by reducing the public deficit. But behind this conciliatory image lies a far-right leader who has drawn ever closer to Donald Trump, even going so far as to imitate him on the domestic stage.

title: Fighting their own country: Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians are forcibly conscripted by Russia
subhead: Moscow is pursuing a policy of forced Russification and militarization in occupied territories, aiming to turn the local population into soldiers. These Ukrainians account for one quarter of the prisoners of war held by Kyiv, Le Monde reveals.

title: Louvre museum director admits jewel heist 'was not inevitable'
subhead: Three days after the spectacular theft of eight French crown jewels, Laurence des Cars appeared before the Sénat's culture committee for nearly three hours.
